author: Univision
title: Policía de Culver City recupera remolque con regalos robados de una asociación y salva la Navidad | Univision 34 Los Angeles KMEX | Univision
text:
LOS ÁNGELES, California.- Esta temporada navideña la s asociaciones que recaudan juguetes para los más necesitados fueron blanco de los ladrones en todo California, dejando a varios niños sin un solo regalo. Pero en Culver City la policía hizo la diferencia.
El 22 de noviembre un remolque lleno de juguetes de Walk 'n Rollers —asociación que no solo da regalos a los niños sino que los alienta a tener actividad física— fue robado, tras darse el aviso a las autoridades, la Policía de Culver City comenzó a trabajar para recuperarlo, lo que parecía algo muy difícil, pero lo logró.
La policía salvó la Navidad para Walk 'n Rollers, no solo recuperó el remolque robado, también logró el arresto de un sospechoso y reunió recursos para reemplazar el equipo robado, pues no estaba completo, a tiempo para las fiestas.
Más sobre Navidad
UNIVISION 34 LOS ANGELES En imágenes: Así inició la temporada navideña con Hollywood Christmas Parade 11 Contenidos “Reconociendo que muchos scooters, bicicletas y equipos no se recuperaron, la policía de Culver City reunió recursos y trabajó para reemplazar los artículos. Días antes de Navidad y Hanukkah, los miembros del departamento ensamblaron bicicletas y equipo. Justo antes de las vacaciones, los oficiales entregaron las bicicletas, los scooters, los cascos y el equipo al líder de Walk 'n Rollers, Jim Shanman”, se lee en la cuenta de Instagram de la Policía.
Mediante su red social, el Departamento de Policía de Culver City agradeció a todos los que se sumaron al esfuerzo por regresar la Navidad que había sido robada, destacado el “tremendo trabajo” de los agentes que participaron en la recuperación, así como a los donantes de la Fundación de la Policía de Culver City y Target, “fue un esfuerzo de equipo para unirse en apoyo de esta víctima de robo”.
Te puede interesar: Cargando galería Comparte RELACIONADOS: Regalos • Policía •
topics: Crime, Law and Justice->robbery and theft

author: Michael Seiden
title: Man driving stolen SUV shot by police in Walgreens parking lot, GBI says – WSB-TV Channel 2 - Atlanta
text: CHAMBLEE, Ga. — The Georgia Bureau of Investigation is investigating [after an officer-involved shooting in Chamblee](https://www.wsbtv.com/news/local/dekalb-county/officer-involved-shooting-investigation-underway-near-dekalb-county-walgreens-police-say/NJUMU6ATARHJ5G443ZKUNBJTJE/) on Thursday morning. Investigators said officers pulled over a suspected stolen SUV around 7:45 a.m. in a Walgreens parking lot in the 5300 block of Peachtree Boulevard. At some point during the stop, an officer fired his gun and the driver was hit. “There was more than one shot fired. As far as the number of times the person was that has not been determined by any of here,” Chamblee Police Chief Michael Dieppa said. [DOWNLOAD: [Free WSB-TV News app for alerts as news breaks](https://www.wsbtv.com/smart-tv/)] Investigators have not said what led up to the shooting. It’s also unclear if the driver was armed or if he fired any shots at officers. Thursday afternoon, the [GBI identified the suspect as Jeremiah Quincy Kinard](https://gbi.georgia.gov/press-releases/2023-12-28/gbi-investigates-officer-involved-shooting-chamblee-ga), 24 of Auburn, Ga. He’s still receiving medical treatment, according to the GBI. No officers were injured. TRENDING STORIES: [Atlanta man can only be taken off life support with this legal document, family says](https://www.wsbtv.com/news/local/atlanta/atlanta-man-can-only-be-taken-off-life-support-with-this-legal-document-family-says/WWQAZQKDPZE7NKAOXGFIX4GCEM/) [19-year-old arrested for shooting, killing woman inside Atlanta McDonald’s, police say](https://www.wsbtv.com/news/local/atlanta/19-year-old-arrested-shooting-killing-woman-inside-atlanta-mcdonalds-police-say/64CFUV2EXVFNJB5Q5OF2QF4JTU/) [Here’s why Georgia officials say there’s a “severe” SNAP delay across the state](https://www.wsbtv.com/news/local/atlanta/heres-why-georgia-officials-say-theres-severe-snap-delay-across-state/CMLW43IGBVHURJSQ6IVMELF6BA/) Neighbors who live adjacent to the shooting scene told Channel 2 Action News that they were surprised to see crime tape near their homes. “It looks pretty crazy,” Danielle Fletcher, a dental hygienist who lives down the street from the Walgreens, said. “There’s an officer that lives in my building, so I just kind of came down to look at the cars to make sure none of them were him.” Thursday’s incident marked the 103rd officer-involved shooting of 2023, according to GBI. Last year, GBI responded to 112. [SIGN UP: [WSB-TV Daily Headlines Newsletter](https://membercenter.wsbtv.com/newsletters)] IN OTHER NEWS: ©2023 Cox Media Group

author: Kulwinder Sandhu
title: 37 trees found axed in Nuh, case registered - The Tribune
text:
37 trees found axed in Nuh, case registered
At least 37 trees were found axed near the Gurgaon Canal passing through Godhola village in Nuh district, said local police officials.
On the complaint of a Forest Department official, the police have registered a case against 10 people, of whom four have been identified and named in an FIR registered at the Punhana police station.
Vinod Kumar, beat in-charge of the Forest Department had stated that during a routine patrolling from the Godhola bridge to the Laharwadi bridge, he found that a large number of trees had been cut down.
When the entire area was inspected, at least 37 trees were found axed. Upon being questioned, locals said people living nearby had cut down the trees.
The Punhana police have registered a case against Tayyab and Sajid, both residents of Tusaini village; Hakku and Hamid, both residents of Laharwadi village; and six unidentified persons. Preliminary investigations revealed that these trees were sold in the Punhana timber market. The police officials were trying to identify those who bought these trees.

author: Eduardo Córdova
title: Un muerto, vehículos quemados y 500 semáforos apagados: estas son las consecuencias de las fuertes lluvias y viento
text:
Un muerto, dos heridos, tres vehículos incendiados, árboles caídos y múltiples cortes de luz es el saldo hasta este viernes del sistema frontal en la Región Metropolitana, que fue azotada durante la noche por fuertes ráfagas de viento.
Asimismo, la Superintendencia de Electricidad y Combustibles (SEC) informó que a las 7:15 horas, 631.459 clientes en la Región Metropolitana se encuentran sin suministro eléctrico .
El incidente más grave ocurrió en la intersección de Gladys Marín con Las Torres, en la comuna de Estación Central, donde una palmera se desplomó sobre un vehículo con tres personas en su interior .
El sistema frontal golpea con fuerza la RM, provocando la caída de árboles y voladuras de techos.
Una de las personas falleció debido al impacto , y las otras dos resultaron heridas, por lo que fueron trasladadas a la ex Posta Central.
“Debido al sistema frontal, de los vientos, cae una de estas palmeras encima del vehículo” , explicó el capitán Jorge Salazar.
Por otro lado, en Froilán Roa con Bernardo Leighton, en la comuna de Macul, tres vehículos se incendiaron después de que un árbol cayera sobre el tendido eléctrico .
Los cables electrificados alcanzaron a uno de los autos, que comenzó a arder, y el fuego se extendió a otros dos vehículos estacionados .
PELIGRO EN LAS CALLES
TransporteInforma de la Región Metropolitana (RM) reportó varias advertencias para circular por las calles de Santiago.
Una de las más importantes es que aproximadamente 500 semáforos están apagados en toda la RM debido a cortes de energía o daños causados por el temporal de viento durante esta madrugada .
Además, la Alameda al oriente está “totalmente bloqueada a la altura de Almirante Latorre por caída de árbol” .
“Todo el flujo desviado en ese punto de Santiago” , añade una publicación en “X”.
Por la misma vía, también recomendó en la comuna de Las Condes “no transitar hacia Pdte. Riesco 4902, frente al Colegio Alcázar por cables cortados y electrificados en la vía bajo la lluvia” .
En Quinta Normal, hay “restricción de tránsito en vía local de General Velásquez con San Pablo debido a caída de árboles y corte de cables” .
Medios de transporte: Por su parte, el Aeropuerto de Santiago suspendió momentáneamente sus operaciones debido a vientos que superaron los 120 kilómetros por hora , pero a las 4:10 horas, la Dirección General de Aeronáutica Civil informó la reanudación de los vuelos.
En su cuenta de “X”, informaron que “el Aeropuerto de Santiago está operativo luego de una interrupción preventiva, debido a las condiciones climáticas de las últimas horas” .
“Recomendamos verificar el estado de su vuelo directamente con su aerolínea, frente a eventuales modificaciones” , añadió el terminal aéreo.

author: Shira Kramer
title: YOU SHOULD KNOW … Bunny Dachs
text:
Bunny Dachs (Courtesy of Bunny Dachs) Bunny Dachs, 33, loves helping seniors age gracefully.
After growing up in Pikesville and attending Bais Yaakov of Baltimore, Dachs received a bachelor of arts degree from Drexel University in health service administration. She then furthered her education at Touro University, where she received a master’s degree in business administration with a focus in health care. Dachs currently owns Bunny’s Home Care, where the mission is “to honor the people who deserve it most.”
Bunny and Yaakov Dachs live in Pikesville with their four children.
What does your job entail?
We hire caregivers, home health care aids and certified nursing assistants and we match them up with seniors or really anybody in the community that needs help with any daily living activities. We kind of do matchmaking, matching up the right caregiver with the person who needs those caregiver services.
What’s your favorite part about your job?
When we get feedback from a client or client’s family. Seeing what our matchmaking and our efforts have done to improve the lives of seniors is the best feeling, and seeing how it gives the families of the seniors relief that they have somebody in their life caring for them.
All the hard work we do makes it worth it for those moments.
Why is this industry so important?
It’s really important because, as the baby boomer generation is starting to age, more and more people need help. People are living longer, so they’re needing help longer, either in their homes or in facilities, but a lot of their kids are still working. Some people drop everything in their lives to care for their loved one. It’s beautiful, but not everybody has that luxury capability. They need help and they need someone to help them. It’s super-important because we want seniors to live with dignity. We want them to age with dignity.
What advice do you have for children of seniors who might not know where to turn?
They should always call if they see any resource of somebody who can help with any aspect of senior care. Calling doesn’t cost anything. It just costs their time. You don’t know what advice you’re going to get that you didn’t even realize could be helpful for you and your situation. Don’t discredit that; make the phone call. You can call any senior provider and if they don’t have what you need, they usually can refer you to the right person.
How would you describe your relationship with Judaism?
I have a very good relationship with Judaism. I grew up Orthodox. I went to Bais Yaakov, my dad went to yeshiva, my mom’s father was a rabbi in Philadelphia. But we were a very open-minded household. We were unique in that way where even if we grew up Orthodox, we’re still open minded to all different sects of Judaism. I have friends that run the gamut of religiousness and they’re still my friends. Some of them grew up Orthodox, some of them didn’t. I grew up in a very open home. We had people all the time staying at our house. We had people living at our house. We had people coming for every Shabbos meal.
It was always a revolving door for people. There was no judgement ever about anybody. It really gave you a good feeling about how we don’t judge each other. We love each other for being Jewish.
Outside of work, what do you do for fun?
I love yoga. I like that it’s not just a physical exercise; it’s a mental exercise. It’s better than therapy. You go to yoga and you get to release everything from the day and move your body and be one with your breath. It really is a good mental and physical release from anything that you’re dealing with throughout your day.
What do you like about working in the Baltimore community?
I love working in the Baltimore community. I like to be able to help people that I have a connection with and other people I get to meet. It’s nice being able to meet new people. People in the Baltimore community are really nice and they’re my people. That’s where I grew up.
Shira Kramer is a freelance writer.

author: NewsBreak Original
title: More than 30,000 Boeing workers to strike after turning down contract proposal
text:
By Clyde Hughes ,
1 hours ago Sept. 13 (UPI) -- More than 30,000 Boeing workers will go on strike starting Friday after turning down a tentative contract proposal hammered out by the company and union negotiators.
The Boeing logo hangs from the Boeing Building, international headquarters in Chicago on March 31, 2011. One of Boeing's largest unions went on strike Friday morning. File Photo by Brian Kersey/UPI Members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers voted 94.6% to reject the agreement, while 96% voted in favor of a strike.
"We strike at midnight," IAM District 751 President Jon Holden said at a press conference on Thursday.
The strike will shut down aircraft assembly at Boeing plants in Seattle, with stoppages also expected in Portland, Ore., and California.
The agreement put before workers would have increased wages by 25%, slashed employee contribution to health care costs and ensured that Boeing's next plane would be constructed at its union plants and not its non-union sites in South Carolina
But contract foes said raises of about 40% were needed along with updates to its pension plan. Boeing executives, though, claimed it was the best contract the company has ever offered a union.
Holden called the stoppage an "unfair labor practice strike," saying workers at the factories faced "discriminatory conduct, coercive questioning, unlawful surveillance," adding that the union had received an "unlawful promise of benefits."
Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg, who has been leading the company for less than two months, said a strike could hobble its recovery and called for the union to accept the deal.
"We have achieved everything we could in bargaining, short of a strike," Holden told members in a message before the voting. "We recommended acceptance because we can't guarantee we can achieve more in a strike.
"But that is your decision to make and is a decision that we will protect and support, no matter what."
Expand All Read in NewsBreak
